The Real Leadership Lessons of Steve Jobs

Six months after Job's death, the author of his best-selling biography identifies the practices that every CEO can try to emulate. by Walter lsaacson

His saga is the entrepreneurial creation myth writ large: steve Jobs cofounded Apple in his parents' garage in 1976, returned to rescue it from near bankruptcy in 1997, and by the time he died, in October 2011, had built it into the world's most valuable company. Along the way he helped to transform seven industries: personal computing, animated movies, music, phones, tablet computing, retail stores, and digital publishing. He thus belongs in the pantheon of a saint, but long after their personalities are forgotten, history will remember how they applied imagination to technology and business.
